title: Managed OpenClaw for Legal Firms in London

hero_subtitle: Deploy a dedicated OpenClaw server in 60 seconds. Maintain absolute privilege with an instance that never shares or trains on your client data.
pain_point: Standard AI services and manual OpenClaw setups compromise solicitor-client privilege by processing data on shared infrastructure.
solution: CloseClaw provides a managed OpenClaw environment where your data stays on your own private server — never shared, never trained on.
regulation_name: SRA Code of Conduct 2019 & UK GDPR
compliance_detail: The Solicitors Regulation Authority Code of Conduct 2019 requires UK solicitors to maintain the confidentiality of client information at all times. Standard cloud AI platforms process queries on shared infrastructure, creating a clear breach risk. The SRA explicitly flagged AI tools as a professional conduct risk in its 2024 guidance notes, and UK GDPR Article 9 imposes additional restrictions on sensitive legal data transferred to US-based AI providers.
local_context: London hosts more than 14,000 regulated law firms and is the world's leading jurisdiction for international arbitration and cross-border M&A work. Post-Brexit, UK solicitors navigate dual GDPR and UK GDPR obligations that further restrict data transfers to US-based AI providers. The concentration of global legal deals and NDA-protected data makes AI confidentiality a board-level risk for any London practice.
workflow_example: A partner at a Magic Circle firm uses CloseClaw to review 200-page disclosure bundles overnight, drafting privilege logs and identifying relevant documents — all on a private server that never connected to a third-party network.

regulation_name: DSGVO (German GDPR) Article 9 — Special Category Health Data
compliance_detail: Germany's Datenschutz-Grundverordnung (DSGVO) places healthcare data under some of Europe's strictest protections. Processing health data on shared AI infrastructure constitutes an unlawful transfer under Article 9 without explicit patient consent. The Berlin data protection authority (BlnBDI) has issued specific guidance warning medical institutions against using public AI tools for patient-related workflows.
local_context: Berlin has grown into Germany's largest health-tech hub, home to over 2,000 health startups and world-class research institutions including the Charité — one of Europe's largest university hospitals. The city's research institutions handle some of Europe's most sensitive medical datasets, including longitudinal patient cohort studies that would be catastrophically exposed by a breach involving a shared AI platform.

pain_point: Amsterdam tech companies handling proprietary code, product roadmaps, and user data face GDPR obligations that shared AI platforms cannot meet for professional data processing.
solution: CloseClaw gives Amsterdam tech firms a private OpenClaw server — a dedicated instance compliant with GDPR requirements and isolated from all shared infrastructure.
regulation_name: GDPR Article 28 and EU NIS2 Directive (effective October 2024)
compliance_detail: Amsterdam tech companies processing EU personal data must comply with GDPR, including Article 28 requirements for processor agreements when using third-party AI tools. The NIS2 Directive (effective October 2024) additionally requires organisations in essential and important sectors to implement 'appropriate technical and organisational measures' for AI-assisted workflows. The Dutch Data Protection Authority (AP) has been among the most active GDPR enforcers in the EU, creating a high-stakes compliance environment for Amsterdam tech companies.
local_context: Amsterdam's tech ecosystem has emerged as one of Europe's most significant, anchored by Booking.com, TomTom, Adyen, and thousands of scale-ups and digital natives. The city's unique position as a European HQ hub for global tech companies — housing the EMEA offices of Uber, Netflix, and Tesla — means Amsterdam tech teams frequently process data subject to multiple EU member state GDPR implementations simultaneously.
workflow_example: An Amsterdam scale-up's product team uses CloseClaw to draft technical specifications, analyse user research data, and generate API documentation — all on a private server that satisfies GDPR Article 28 processor requirements and NIS2 technical security standards.

title: Private AI Agent for New York HR and Executive Recruiting

private AI human resources New York
hero_title: Managed OpenClaw: Private AI for New York HR Teams
hero_subtitle: Your own OpenClaw server for HR workflows — candidate screening, job description drafting, and compensation research — all on private, isolated infrastructure.
pain_point: New York HR teams and executive recruiters handling confidential compensation data and candidate profiles cannot safely process this through shared AI platforms.
solution: CloseClaw provides a dedicated OpenClaw instance for HR teams — a private server where candidate data, salary benchmarks, and hiring strategies never leave your control.
regulation_name: NYC Local Law 144 on Automated Employment Decision Tools (AEDT)
compliance_detail: New York City Local Law 144 (effective July 2023) is one of the world's first laws specifically governing AI in HR and hiring contexts. It requires employers using automated employment decision tools to conduct annual bias audits and provide candidate notifications. NYC HR teams and recruiting firms using shared AI platforms for candidate screening face both Local Law 144 compliance requirements and EEOC guidance on AI in employment. Multi-tenant AI tools create additional data protection obligations under New York's data privacy framework.
local_context: New York City's HR and recruiting sector is the world's largest, with over 1,800 executive search firms, thousands of HR departments in Fortune 500 companies, and the highest concentration of corporate HR leaders globally. The city's implementation of Local Law 144 has made it the global reference point for AI regulation in employment contexts, attracting regulatory attention from EEOC and state regulators across the US.
workflow_example: A New York executive search firm uses CloseClaw to research candidate backgrounds, draft position specifications, and analyse compensation benchmarks — all on a private server where C-suite candidate identities and client talent strategies are completely protected from competitive exposure.
